Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Randomness in Geometry and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves using ideas from dynamical systems, probability theory and geometry to understand randomness in various geometric and dynamical contexts. The PI is developing new measures of complexity for parabolic dynamical systems using spacing statistics and gap distributions, and using renormalization methods to compute these invariants. The PI and his collaborators are also creating new notions of random geometric objects and structures, by placing appropriate measures on moduli spaces of geometric objects, and understanding properties of these random objects by computing moments of various functions with respect to these measures.

The measures of complexity are being designed in this project are constructed to help detect new types of chaotic (`sensitive dependence on initial conditions') behavior of time evolution of physical systems in new situations, such as the motion of an electron on the Fermi surface of a metal in the presence of a magnetic field. Understanding the geometry and measure theory of moduli space of geometric objects is being used by the PI and a team of engineers in modeling and optimizing the performance of a lithium-ion battery. The research in this project develops and uses many computational experiments, as well as visualizations and animations of the models. Many of these are prepared by teams of students in the lllinois Geometry Lab (IGL), a facility founded by the PI, focusing on research, visualization and community engagement. The educational component of this award centers on development and expansion of the IGL, which involves a broad variety of participants: all the way from preschoolers to graduate students to teachers and educators. The activities of the IGL introduce them to mathematics as an exploratory endeavor, and develop a community of mathematical explorers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many of the outcomes of this project center on a simple model problem in Newtonian mechanics:  understanding the motion of a ball on a walled table shaped like a polygon. The ball starts rolling in a fixed direction, and we make two important simplifying assumptions: the table has no friction; and when the ball hits a wall, it bounces off at the same angle as it hits, and doesn?t slow down. When a ball starts moving it continues at its initial speed for all time, unless it ends up in a corner.

Polygonal billiards are examples of parabolic systems: they sit on the boundary between hyperbolic systems (very disordered) and elliptic systems (highly ordered). A key tool in many of the results in this project is renormalization. This catch-all term refers, in this setting, to the idea of speeding up the system in order to observe long-term behavior of the original system at shorter time scales. Imagine replacing the billiard ball by one moving faster, and as the speed increases, by the movement of a focused beam of light in a mirrored polygonal room.

Billiards and related dynamical systems have been the subject of active research for more than one hundred years, not just for their appeal as a ?toy model?, but because they are wonderfully flexible. The techniques used to study billiards can be used to study the movement of electrons (in the presence of a magnetic field) on Fermi surfaces of metals; potential flows in heterogeneous materials; and more recently, supersymmetric quantum field theories.

A remarkable result of Kerckhoff-Masur-Smillie states that in a billiard table with rational angles, a trajectory in a random direction spreads evenly across the table. With Jon Chaika, we determined the size of the set of directions that don?t satisfy these long-term estimates.

With Alex Eskin and Anton Zorich, we counted special trajectories for a wide range of rectilinear billiard tables. You can see two examples in the images of rectilinear tables- surprisingly, the number of trajectories between two corners turns out to grow in the same way on the two tables, despite their different geometry. A key tool in this result was our resolution conjecture of Kontsevich on volumes of moduli spaces, which are spaces of geometries on surfaces.

A big focus of this project was the statistics of various point clouds associated to special billiard trajectories: developing a library of techniques, and implementing them in collaboration with J. Chaika and S. Lelievre in some important special cases. I used similar ideas in my work with Cobeli-Zaharescu to understand the geometry and statistics of certain fractals known as Apollonian circle packings, which you can see in the attached image. This project also was part of the Illinois Geometry Lab (IGL), which you can read about more below.

With Y. Cheung and H. Masur, we showed that the variance of point clouds associated to billiards is finite, opening up new directions of research, and a recent paper with F. Arana Herrera, we show that a similar result is true for point clouds associated to hyperbolic surfaces.

in joint work with Aulicino and Aulicino-Hooper, we apply ideas from billiards to study geometric properties of polyhedra, including Platonic solids, recently resolving a century-old problem on straight-line trajectories on the dodecahedron, which you can see in the attached figure. This project highlights another aspect of my work, the development of computational techniques to prove fundamental mathematical results. This philosophy un- derlies my work as the founder and director of the Washington Experimental Mathematics Lab (WXML) (http://www.wxml.math.washington.edu/), which builds a community around vertically integrated undergraduate research in mathematics.

The WXML (and previously, the Illinois Geometry Lab (or IGL)) were the centerpiece of the educational and broader impacts of this project. Via the WXML, we created an environment for exploratory undergraduate research in mathematics, with 30-40 participants a quarter. A beautiful image from a project I led on triply periodic polyhedral surfaces is attached. At Illinois, the IGL has grown to 70-80 students participating each quarter. These labs are also part of an umbrella organiztion, Geometry Labs United (GLU), which brings together exploratory math labs across the country. As part of this project, we hosted GLU conferences in Urbana and in Seattle, and this summer, there will be a virtual conference at ICERM in Providence.

Via the WXML, we have hosted Math Teacher's Circles for Seattle Public Schools teachers, Math Circles for indigenous youth at the Licton Springs school, and we've provided support for the Navajo Nation Mathematics Circles. We've also hosted students from UW's Math Academy for summer high school research projects. 

Finally, I've appeared on podcasts (https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/roots-of-unity/jayadev-athreyas-favorite-theorem/) and YouTube channels (https://www.numberphile.com/videos/yellow-brick-road) to share my work, and was a consultant on a documentary (http://www.zalafilms.com/secrets/) about the late Maryam Mirzakhani.
